where kğ‘˜k denotes the magnitude of discontinuity and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon represents a zero-mean Gaussian noise term defined only in [0,2â€‹Ï€]02ğœ‹[0,2\pi] with standard deviation ÏƒÏµsubscriptğœitalic-Ïµ\sigma_{\epsilon}.
In this regard, a task distribution pâ€‹(Î»)ğ‘ğœ†p(\lambda) can be defined by drawing randomly frequency values Î»={Ï‰1,Ï‰2}ğœ†subscriptğœ”1subscriptğœ”2\lambda=\{\omega_{1},\omega_{2}\} from ğ’°[Ï‰1,mâ€‹iâ€‹n,Ï‰1,mâ€‹aâ€‹x]subscriptğ’°subscriptğœ”1ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœ”1ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\mathscr{U}_{[\omega_{1,min},\omega_{1,max}]} and ğ’°[Ï‰2,mâ€‹iâ€‹n,Ï‰2,mâ€‹aâ€‹x]subscriptğ’°subscriptğœ”2ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœ”2ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\mathscr{U}_{[\omega_{2,min},\omega_{2,max}]}, respectively, where ğ’°ğ’°\mathscr{U} denotes a uniform distribution.
The defined task distribution is used in this section for function approximation.
The values of the fixed parameters used in this example can be found in TableÂ 1.

For evaluating the performance of the captured learned loss snapshots, we use them for meta-testing on 101010 OOD tasks and compare with standard loss functions from TableÂ A.1.
Specifically, we train with Adam for 50,0005000050{,}000 iterations 101010 tasks using 181818 different loss functions (666 FFN, 666 LAL and 666 standard) and record the rl2 error on 1,00010001{,}000 exact solution datapoints.
The test tasks are sampled from a distribution defined by combining Eq.Â (29) with k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 and ÏƒÏµ=0.2subscriptğœitalic-Ïµ0.2\sigma_{\epsilon}=0.2, and with the uniform distributions ğ’°[Ï‰1,mâ€‹iâ€‹n,Ï‰1,mâ€‹aâ€‹x]subscriptğ’°subscriptğœ”1ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœ”1ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\mathscr{U}_{[\omega_{1,min},\omega_{1,max}]} and ğ’°[Ï‰2,mâ€‹iâ€‹n,Ï‰2,mâ€‹aâ€‹x]subscriptğ’°subscriptğœ”2ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœ”2ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\mathscr{U}_{[\omega_{2,min},\omega_{2,max}]}, where {Ï‰1,mâ€‹iâ€‹n,Ï‰1,mâ€‹aâ€‹x,Ï‰2,mâ€‹iâ€‹n,Ï‰2,mâ€‹aâ€‹x}subscriptğœ”1ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœ”1ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğœ”2ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœ”2ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\{\omega_{1,min},\omega_{1,max},\omega_{2,min},\omega_{2,max}\} are shown in TableÂ 1.
The minimum rl2 error results are shown in Fig.Â 3.
We see that the loss functions learned with the FFN parametrization do not generalize well, whereas the ones learned with the LAL parametrization achieve an average minimum rl2 error that is smaller than the error corresponding to all the other considered loss functions by at least 15%percent1515\%.
For example, the average minimum rl2 error for LAL 4 is approximately 17%percent1717\% and is obtained (on average) close to iteration 20,0002000020{,}000, whereas the corresponding error for MSE is approximately 20%percent2020\% and is obtained (on average) close to iteration 50,0005000050{,}000.
Despite the improvement demonstrated in this example, in Fig.Â 10 we show for the advection equation example that the performance of the learned loss depends on the exponential decay parameters of Adam that control the dependence of the updates on the gradient history.

The task distribution parameters used in meta-training are shown in TableÂ 2.
The meta-training design options are the same as in SectionÂ 4.2 except for the fact that objective function weights are not meta-learned.
Furthermore, the PINN architecture consists of 333 hidden layers with 202020 neurons each and tâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹hğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘›â„tanh activation function.

For evaluating the performance of the captured learned loss snapshots, we employ them for meta-testing on 555 OOD tasks and compare with standard loss functions from TableÂ A.1.
Specifically, we train with SGD for 20,0002000020{,}000 iterations with learning rate 0.010.010.01 (same as in meta-training) 555 tasks using learned and standard loss functions and record the rl2 error on 2,50025002{,}500 exact solution datapoints.
The OOD test tasks are drawn based on the parameter limits shown in TableÂ 2.
In addition, to increase the difficulty of OOD meta-testing, we also draw random architectures to be used in meta-testing that are different than the meta-training architecture; the number of hidden layers is drawn from ğ’°[2,5]subscriptğ’°25\mathscr{U}_{[2,5]} and the number of neurons in each layer from ğ’°[15,55]subscriptğ’°1555\mathscr{U}_{[15,55]}.
A learned loss that performs equally well for architectures not used in meta-training is desirable if, for example, we seek to optimize the PINN architecture with a fixed learned loss.

For evaluating the performance of the captured learned loss snapshots, we train with SGD for 20,0002000020{,}000 iterations with learning rate 0.010.010.01 (same as in meta-training) 555 OOD tasks using learned and standard loss functions and record the rl2 error on 10,0001000010{,}000 exact solution datapoints.
Regarding learned losses, we employ the ones obtained with single data and with objective function weights meta-learning, as they performed better in our experiments.
The OOD test tasks are drawn based on the parameter limits shown in TableÂ 2 and the random architectures used are drawn in the same way as in SectionÂ 4.3.

In Fig.Â 11, we show the final loss functions (FFN and LAL parametrizations) as obtained with SGD and Adam as inner optimizers.
In addition, in Fig.Â 11 we include the loss functions obtained using the exact solution data in the outer objective instead of the composite PINNs loss of Eq.Â (18).
In the considered example, this data is available because a fabricated solution is used, whereas in practice this data may be originating from a numerical solver or from measurements.
This is referred to as double data (DD) in the plots because different data is used for the inner and for the outer objective; single data is denoted as SD.
The number of datapoints used for evaluating the outer objective of Eq.Â (18) is shown in TableÂ 3, whereas the corresponding number for the inner objective of Eq.Â (17) is the same as the single-data case in TableÂ 3.
